title: 114_hr2324
content: The "Small Lands Tracts Conveyance Act" allows for special conveyance authority regarding small parcels of national forest system land and public lands. The "Small Lands Tracts Conveyance Act" defines terms like "adjacent landholder" as a holder of non-Federal land bordering eligible Federal lands parcels, "Director concerned" as the Director of the Bureau of Land Management for a State, and "eligible Federal lands parcel" as National Forest System land or public lands sharing boundaries with non-Federal land. The "Small Lands Tracts Conveyance Act" defines "exceptional resource" as a valuable scientific, historic, cultural, or recreational resource on public lands that meets specific criteria, excluding areas with endangered species habitats or existing non-Federal rights. The "Small Lands Tracts Conveyance Act" defines "exceptional resource" as a valuable scientific, historic, cultural, or recreational resource on public lands that requires extraordinary conservation and protection for the benefit of the public. The term "Indian tribe" and "National Forest System land" are also defined within the Act. The term "land" refers to land within the National Forest System, excluding land managed by the Forest Service in certain designated areas. The term "public lands" includes various designated areas such as national scenic areas, research natural areas, national landmarks, wilderness areas, and more, as defined in the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976. It does not include lands managed by the Bureau of Land Management in specific conservation areas. The term "public lands" encompasses various designated areas like national monuments, conservation areas, recreation areas, scenic areas, natural landmarks, wilderness areas, and more. The Regional Forester concerned refers to the Regional Forester with jurisdiction over National Forest System land in a specific Forest Service Region. The selection of parcels for conveyance is also discussed. The Regional Forester with jurisdiction over National Forest System land in a specific Forest Service Region selects eligible Federal lands parcels for conveyance either in response to a request from an adjacent landholder or upon recommendation from the Bureau of Land Management or National Forest System. Adjacent landholders can request conveyance through a process created by the Secretaries of Agriculture and the Interior. The Secretaries of Agriculture and the Interior will establish a process for adjacent landholders to request purchasing eligible Federal lands parcels. The process must align with existing public purchase request procedures of the Forest Service and the Bureau of Land Management. It will be accessible to the public online within 90 days of the Act's enactment. The process for adjacent landholders to request purchasing eligible Federal lands parcels will be established by the Secretaries of Agriculture and the Interior. The Director or Regional Forester will review the parcel within 30 days to determine eligibility for conveyance. If the parcel does not meet the criteria, the request may be rejected. If a parcel of National Forest System land or public lands covered by an adjacent landholder request fails to meet the criteria for eligible Federal lands parcel, the concerned Director or Regional Forester must provide the landowner with a written explanation detailing the reasons for rejection, including which elements of the definition the parcel fails to satisfy and the potential impact of continued administration by the Bureau of Land Management or the Forest Service on the parcel and surrounding economy. The Federal Government may reject a request for an eligible Federal lands parcel if it does not meet the criteria, with reasons for rejection provided. The parcel size is limited to 160 acres unless approved for more by the Director or Regional Forester. Each adjacent landholder can only acquire one parcel. The Director or Regional Forester must provide public notice of available eligible Federal lands parcels, even if they share a boundary with only one non-Federal parcel or multiple parcels owned by the same individual. Adjacent landholders can acquire one eligible parcel per year, with the option to acquire additional parcels if each is less than 160 acres, or if approved for more acreage by the Director or Regional Forester. The Director or Regional Forester must provide public notice of available eligible Federal lands parcels, even if they share a boundary with only one non-Federal parcel or multiple parcels owned by the same individual. Adjacent landholders can acquire one eligible parcel per year through negotiated sale. When eligible public lands parcels share a boundary with non-Federal land, competitive bidding procedures are used for their sale. Offers that do not meet the minimum consideration required can be rejected, with the opportunity for appeal. Compliance with local planning and zoning is a condition for conveyance of these parcels. When selling eligible public lands parcels that border non-Federal land, compliance with local land use ordinances and zoning plans is required. The conveyance of these parcels is done through a quitclaim deed transferring all rights, including the mineral estate, to the purchaser. An appeals process is available if a request for selection of a parcel is rejected by the Director or Regional Forester. The Regional Forester or Director shall provide an appeals process for reconsideration of rejected requests or offers for conveyance of National Forest System land or public lands. The expedited Forest Service appeals process under section 322(d) of Public Law 102-381 (16 U.S.C. 1612 note) will be used, with the Administering official being the Director or Regional Forester concerned. The Director or Regional Forester will require a cash payment equal to the fair market value for the sale of eligible Federal lands parcels. The fair market value will be determined by an appraisal submitted by the adjacent landholder. The Director or Regional Forester will require a cash payment equal to the fair market value for the sale of eligible Federal lands parcels. An appraisal submitted by the adjacent landholder will determine the fair market value, with a 45-day window for rejection. If rejected, a new appraisal must be conducted within 30 days. The Secretary of the Treasury will establish a special fund for the collection and distribution of funds from the conveyance of the parcels. The funds collected from the conveyance of eligible Federal lands parcels will be deposited into a Treasury fund. These funds will be distributed annually to States where the Federal Government owns more than 33% of the land area, with 50% going to the State of conveyance and the remaining 50% distributed elsewhere. The funds from the conveyance of Federal lands will be distributed to States, with 50% going to the State of conveyance and the remaining 50% divided equally among other States. States receiving funds must use them to purchase eligible Federal lands and comply with Federal requirements such as the Endangered Species Act. The Director or Regional Forester must require the purchaser to pay for conveyance costs, including survey, appraisal, environmental documentation, and administrative costs. Refunds are given for any excess amounts collected. The Director or Regional Forester must collect payment from the purchaser for conveyance costs, including survey, appraisal, and administrative costs. Any excess amount collected must be refunded to the purchaser and credited back to the fund used for covering the conveyance costs. The conveyance of eligible Federal lands parcels should take no more than 18 months. Such conveyances are categorically excluded from environmental assessment requirements. This conveyance authority is additional to existing sale authority. The conveyance authority for eligible Federal lands parcels should be completed within 18 months and is exempt from environmental assessment requirements. This authority is in addition to existing sale authority under the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976.
